Hi @precog・55 some modest announcements:  We just pushed a couple updates to the dashboard (https://precog.coinmetrics.io).  The changes aren't dramatic but should make it more useable and fix some aspects of the display.  

First, the "Avg Reward" column has been renamed  "Epoch Reward" to better emphasize it only represents one evaluation.  More importantly, we added the "EMA Final Reward" column which is all the previous  "Epoch Reward"s exponentially-moving-averaged; *this* value should correspond fairly closely to the miner weight written to the blockchain and ordering shown on Taostats.  

It will not be perfect because validators don't have exactly equal evaluations and don't all write their data to wandb with the same reliability. But at least as of now there is reasonable agreement (to within ~20 ranks) and it should be more consistent than before.

The dashboard was previously ranking miners according to single epoch score, which is very volatile, and not very reflective of emissions. I believe this led to a lot of the confusion and I apologize for the design, with all things we address with a subnet this slipped through the cracks.  It also required cleaning up the scoring which Peter did last week to clarify the issue.

Finally, several of you noted the absurd spikes in our "top 20 miners avg" plot which showed some nonsense predictions.  As far as I can tell these are due to previously well-performing miners that sporadically give predictions like negative prices (maybe an AI model gone rogue?).  We have changed the *average* to a *median* of the top 20 miners on the dashboard chart, which basically means those massive outliers don't appear unless things are very wrong.
In short, I expect https://precog.coinmetrics.io to show better outputs going forward and more consistent rankings that closely match emissions

Another brief update, is that we have internally started testing the subnet output API.  I was going to write a slightly longer post, but since tomorrow is a holiday and its getting late I'll summarize:

* We are testing a recent/ and historical/ endpoint that provides outputs quite similar to the Miner leaderboard for the most recent epoch and the for an arbitrary window in the past several days.  
* We still need to finalize the design and implement the authentication process. It is likely to require a minimum Alpha balance, but be otherwise free to start.
* Although we will not be charging fees for the foreseeable future, we view this as an essential first step on the road to producing an end-user product that can be consumed and monetized inside and outside of the Bittensor ecosystem 
* We'll try to have approximate timelines ready to share early next week

When the moving average alpha was 0.1, there were additional layers of smoothing being applied as well, this was the technical change we made last week because it was making it difficult to interpret and debug results.  But what I mean is that value of 0.1 is not directly comparable to the current value 0.029 (https://github.com/coinmetrics/precog/blob/v2.5.1/precog/utils/config.py#L202) because the calculation has changed.

Thats why I want to ask what qualitative problem or change you want to see is.  From what I'm understanding, I think you're saying the current reward is *too* stable and you'd like it to react more quickly to each new prediction: in other words jump you up and down the ranks each time you predict.   This is of course a balance, because early on we saw miners complaining they jumped around too much and were upset they got deregistered for a few bad predictions after doing well historically.

The value 0.029 is currently set so that every 2-hours in the past the contribution of the prediction drops by 1/2.  Another way to interpret is each new prediction has 3% contribution, and the previous EMA Miner Weight has 97% contribution.  The last 12 predictions (ie. the most recent hour) will be worth 29% of the final miner weight written to chain.  I am off today but if you'd like I can show my work on Monday.  I think a 29% contribution from the previous hour of prediction is actually quite responsive, but I am open to rebuttals if this is not your experience, I'm just asking to be as detailed as possible with specifically what the frustration is.

I'm not sure, but it sounds like your concern might also have to do with the final rewards being too broadly distributed, and you'd prefer a more peaked reward structure.  This is separate from the prediction rank, but we can consider whether to give a more concentrated share of rewards to the best performing miners, in light of the new evaluation.

Yeah in my opinion, I don’t think the curve should be so smooth and distributed. For example, it was around the top ~150 miners which were getting rewards before, and I think that’s fair.

Also, I think the effect of the averaging before also had a different effect than the exponential moving average. The moving average was calculated based on our predictions but this is actually an EWA based on our weights, which would make our past have much more influence than our current value, but in particular I think the alpha is currently too low of a value

The fact is that the current curve is a lot smoother and I think there should be a bit more emphasis on more recent period as opposed to having such a long memory of weights

I totally agree.
Previously, the incentive curve was so steep that emission was concentrated among the top 20 miners, allowing them to receive high rewards. As a result, miners focused on maximizing the model’s performance, and even with just one miner, they tried to boost the model’s efficiency to earn higher rewards.
However, now that the curve is much more flexible, miners are increasing the number of miners to boost overall rewards rather than improving the model’s performance. Of course, this could turn the subnet into a playground for  REG_BOTs.
If the goal of this subnet is to develop a truly high-performance model, I believe we should revert to the previous mechanism.

In my opinion, I think having a more responsive reward system by having a higher value of alpha would be better because it as miners, it also allows us to see how our models are performing. 

This is because as you mentioned, the current contribution is only around 2% and that every 2-hours in the past the contribution of the prediction drops by 1/2, so it is very hard to determine whether the performance is related to the historical component or whether it is related to the current condition. *Also, this is because having too smooth of a value ultimately focuses more on the past than the present and we know that the market is always in constant change*. It is almost in a sense like trading and how not many people uses EMA for the price or as an indicator because it is not a good reflection of the present (ie: if anything people use moving average more), especially with such a low value of alpha.

Moreover, I understand that the previous incentive structure also added some smoothing mechanism because it took a moving average of our predictions, but ultimately I think that had a much lower "stability" affect than what we are currently doing right now, since we are ultimately smoothing the final weights as opposed to before.

As a result, I really dont think it is necessary to have such a low value of alpha and if anything I think we should actually increase the alpha to a higher value or equal value than before (ie: 0.1).

I hear what you're saying, I agree we've wanted the top miners to get a significant majority of rewards.  I think this is not so related to the moving average which determines the rank over time, but actually has more to do with how we distribute  shares for the different ranks at each epoch. Currently each miner gets 90% of the miner ahead of them, but this may need adjusting for the new mechanism.

We'll discuss it and see what we can change

But isn’t the ranking mechanism the same as before ? 

It was unchanged since it was always 0.9**rank.

The only thing that is a big fluctuation is the moving average alpha.
The issue isn’t related to the ranking but rather the setting of weights after the ranks have been determined.

so its two steps:
* Rank and then convert ranks to Epoch Weight for each miner (`0.9^rank`)
* EMA Epoch Weights over time to get Final Weight final_weight(t) = α\*epoch_weight(t) + (1-α)\*final_weight(t-1)

We streamlined the second step which was previously more complicated.  So even though the first step did not change, how it is used in the final weight changed, and as you noted the exact values have ended up more broad than before

we discussed in DMs but to share my thoughts publicly, the reason I want to consider adjsuting the "decay" (0.9) instead of α value, is because the current alpha gives the last hour of predictions (ie. 12x 5-min evaluations) 30% contribution in the final weight.  

If we increase further I am concerned the final weights become to volatile which is a concern.  However changing the decay for shares-per-rank focuses on rewarding top miners without impacting the responsiveness directly

Changing the decay to 0.85 for example, will just increase the share of epoch-weight to the top 7-8 miners.  I'm not certain this is the solution but in the interest of sharing our thought process

Ultimately both are related, because a miner is not always at rank #1, they may jump between 1-20 for example, so the time-averaging and weight-per-rank are both going to impact final-weight volatility, but we need to think about the best parameters to tune

I don't think it's a good idea to ignore previous evaluations to the extreme.
The goal of this subnet is to get high-quality prediction data.
Prediction is not always accurate, so sometimes it can be good and sometimes it can be bad.
Since the subnet continuously updates the ranking, it can get high-quality predictions at any time.
So even if one miner makes a wrong prediction, another miner can make a right prediction.

In fact, in the past, some top miners were deregistered due to some wrong predictions.
Many participants focused on keeping miners even though their scores were low.
So they created models with non-zero rewards (even if they didn't produce high quality).
They were satisfied even though the reward was close to 0.001.

That's not the goal of this subnet.
We need high-quality models.

ANNOUNCEMENT @precog・55
We are very excited to share at long last the release of the Precog API.  This will serve as a way for anyone with a minimum required Alpha balance to frictionlessly consume the data produced by Precog over the past 30 days.  I’ll be publishing a more formal article soon, but want to get the ball rolling:

At this time a Coldkey with **750.0** SN55 Alpha tokens is required for authentication.  However this is *not* a fee.  To our knowledge we’re one of the first subnets to structure access this way - giving Alpha utility through proof of holding, but not requiring them to be spent.  The goal is to give people the ability experiment with this new product, without committing capital before they know what they’re getting.

* We have a developed a Python client that handles the authentication under the hood.  Instructions for authenticating and signing with your BT wallet are in the ReadMe: https://github.com/coinmetrics/precog-api-utility
* The URL-level API docs can be found here: https://precog-api.coinmetrics.io/docs

I have a question.
How does this API help miners?

So for starters, I'm not sure the Bittensor framework incentivizes subnet owners to directly improve the lives of miners.  As long as there is incentive to be earned the miners presumably will come.  That said, I think developing the subnet as a product and building a business case helps miners in the long term by getting us to monetization and an income stream that can add to the inflationary protocol rewards.

More directly, I would think that savvy miners can find ways to utilize additional signals from their compatriots to adjust their own signal in a beneficial way.  In other words they can observe each other's predictions as an additional data point.

Finally, access to this data is the first concrete use-case for holding Alpha tokens, with promise of additional uses for them in the future.  The more people hold Alpha tokens the more valuable the rewards miners earn become

the interval scoring is described here https://docs.coinmetrics.io/bittensor/precog-methodology/interval-forecast-evaluation.   It is essentially trying to predict the high and low over the 1-hour following hte prediction, the score scales down if youre too wide or miss part of the time series.

Without knowing any details its hard to say for sure, the results are exponentially averaged over the previous hours, so if your previous results were not as accurate that can lower your score.  Also make sure your response is not taking more than ~10 seconds  from when you receive it. The validators have a time limit of 20sec I believe from when they send the request to when they need to recieve a response

Hello @precog・55  community

We’re excited to share some code examples that leverage the Precog API to give a sense of how easy it is to start doing calculations on forecast data.  The script uses code that I’ve used to run some trading simulations using basic strategies using the Precog Forecasts and are evaluated with the the Coin Metrics Reference Rates available through our Community endpoint.  The readme for the scripts (https://github.com/coinmetrics/precog-api-utility/blob/master/analysis_example/analysis_readme.md) also shows the most recent results of this analysis for the past week.  We hope you find it interesting and useful.


Additionally, in order to encourage use of the Precog API, I have requested to lower the required Alpha balance to authenticate from 750 to 250.  I am waiting on approval but hopefully it will be done by tomorrow.

Finally, we’re excited to share that we plan a significant change to the core incentive mechanism which will require Miners to forecast prices for ETH and TAO in addition to BTC.  We will be sharing more details in the next few days, but the code is currently in the final testing stages.  The formal announcement and details will come at least two weeks before implementation to give everyone a chance to to update their miners.

messages.content: Pinned a message.
250 Alpha stake required for API auth  updated

Hello again @precog・55 , as promised we have some more details on changes planned for Precog SN55.

## What’s New
We are finalizing a change to the SN55 incentive mechanism which will require Miners to produce forecasts for two additional assets, ETH and TAO.  Both these assets will require a point and interval forecast just like BTC does currently.  

## How does this affect incentive
The single epoch reward will be updated to be equally weighted across all 3 assets.  Currently the single epoch reward averages the reward share that corresponds to the point and interval forecast, after the update it will average 6 shares corresponding to the different rankings ([point + interval] x [3 asset])

## What do Miners need to change
The request and response format will change from a single float to a list of floats, wish a similar adjustment to the interval forecasts.  @Peter | Yuma  has put together a technical migration guide here: https://gist.github.com/peter-yuma/9b87046a40ee75825e173c17caa8b42a.

## When is this happening
The update will happen no earlier than Monday, September 29th; two weeks and change from today.  We reserve the right to push this date out based on community feedback or internal timelines.
It would be okay that test it on the testnet before updating the mainnet.
We are currently running these changes on testnet on validator UID 0.
